snippet: The European Central Bank chief, Mario Draghi, set off a backlash by investors who were apparently hoping for a bold euro rescue plan.
abstract: News analysis; European Central Bank chief president Mario Draghi sets off a backlash by investors who were apparently hoping for a bold euro rescue plan; he signals the bank is willing to start buying government bonds from troubled countries, but puts the onus on political leaders to move first, and leaves open some crucial questions about how quickly and forcefully it will seek to tame unruly financial markets.

byline.contributor: Raphael Minder contributed reporting from Madrid and Stephen Castle from London.

lead_paragraph: The European Central Bank chief, Mario Draghi, set off a backlash by investors who were apparently hoping for a bold euro rescue plan.

headline.seo: Draghi Edges Closer to Bond Purchases, but Hopes Are Blunted
headline.main: Draghi Edges Closer to Bond Purchases, but Hopes Are Blunted
headline.print_headline: A Lofty Vow Falls Short, and Investors Show Dismay
